Background.graph: Given a causal graph with 9 nodes A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, and 8 edges A->I, B->F, B->H, C->G, D->F, E->G, E->H, F->I.
Background.real_world_meaning: The real world meaning of each node is defined as follows: A represents temperature, B represents education level, C represents job satisfaction, D represents government policies, E represents blood pressure, F represents sales performance, G represents wheather condition, H represents stress level and I represents market demand.
Background.data_info: For those with education level being high, the probability of market demand being high is 0.3304. The probability of education level being low and market demand being low is 0.5156. The probability of education level being high and market demand being high is 0.0816.

Instruction: Consider the probability of sufficiency (PS) of education level on market demand.
Question: Given that education level was low and market demand was low, what is the upper bound of the probability that market demand would have been high if the education level had been high?
given_info: Imagine a self-contained, hypothetical world with only the following conditions, and without any unmentioned factors or causal relationships: Temperature has a direct effect on market demand. Education level has a direct effect on sales performance. Education level has a direct effect on stress level. Job satisfaction has a direct effect on wheather condition. Government policies has a direct effect on sales performance. Blood pressure has a direct effect on wheather condition. Blood pressure has a direct effect on stress level. Sales performance has a direct effect on market demand.

Background.graph: Given a causal graph with 9 nodes A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, I, and 10 edges A->G, A->I, A->D, B->I, C->F, D->E, D->F, E->G, F->H, G->I.
Background.real_world_meaning: The real world meaning of each node is defined as follows: A represents appearance, B represents physical health, C represents mental health, D represents income level, E represents sales performance, F represents talent, G represents traffic congestion, H represents education level and I represents market demand.
Background.data_info: For those with mental health being high, the probability of education level being low is 0.2251. The probability of education level being low is 0.2198. The probability of mental health being low and education level being low is 0.1536.

Instruction: Consider the probability of sufficiency (PS) of mental health on education level.
Question: Given that mental health was low and education level was low, what is the lower bound of the probability that education level would have been high if the mental health had been high?
given_info: Imagine a self-contained, hypothetical world with only the following conditions, and without any unmentioned factors or causal relationships: appearance has a direct effect on traffic congestion. appearance has a direct effect on market demand. appearance has a direct effect on income level. Physical health has a direct effect on market demand. Mental health has a direct effect on talent. Income level has a direct effect on sales performance. Income level has a direct effect on talent. Sales performance has a direct effect on traffic congestion. Talent has a direct effect on education level. Traffic congestion has a direct effect on market demand.
